Table 15.2 Diagnostic criteria
Features required for
Progressive weakness of >1 limb
Areﬂ exia
Features supporting diagnosis
 • Progression over days, up to 4wks
 • Near symmetry of sytoms
 • Sensory symptoms/signs only mild
 • CN involvement (eg bilateral facial weakness)
 • Recovery starts ~2wks after the period of 
progression has ﬁ nished
 • Autonomic dysfunction
 • Absence of fever at onset
 • CSF protein  with CSF WCC <10≈10
6/L
 • Typical electrophysiological tests
Features making diagnosis doubtful
 • Sensory level
 • Marked, persistent asymmetry of 
weakness
 • Severe bowel and bladder dysfunction
 • CSF WCC >50
Variants of Guillain–Barré syndrome include:
Chronic inﬂ ammatory demyelinating polyradiculopathy (CIDP): Character ized 
by a slower onset and recovery.
Miller Fisher syndrome: Comprises of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areﬂ exia. As-
sociated with anti-GQ1b antibodies in the serum.
